author: LA NACION
title: Francia expulsa a un im√°n tunecino "radical": ministro del Interior
text:
Reuters Francia expulsa a un im√°n tunecino "radical": ministro del Interior Reuters 23 de febrero de 2024, 12:21 a. m. ¬∑ 2 min de lectura
PAR√çS, 22 feb (Reuters) - Francia ha expulsado a un cl√©rigo musulm√°n tunecino por "radicalismo" y "comentarios inaceptables", inform√≥ el ministro del Interior, G√©rald Darmanin, en un comunicado difundido en la red social X.
Con el partido de extrema derecha RN a la cabeza en las encuestas para las elecciones europeas de junio, el presidente Emmanuel Macron se ha visto sometido a presiones para que utilice mano dura en cuestiones de inmigraci√≥n e identidad.
"El im√°n radical Mahjoub Mahjoubi acaba de ser expulsado del territorio nacional, menos de 12 horas despu√©s de su detenci√≥n. No permitiremos que se salgan con la suya", afirm√≥ Darmanin en un comunicado en X.
En una declaraci√≥n anterior, Darmanin dijo que hab√≠a dado instrucciones para que se emitiera una orden ministerial de expulsi√≥n contra "este 'im√°n' radical con comentarios inaceptables". "La firmeza es la regla", a√±adi√≥.
En un post que se hizo viral en las redes sociales y del que se hicieron eco ampliamente los medios de comunicaci√≥n franceses, el im√°n se refiri√≥ a "la bandera tricolor" como "sat√°nica".
Mahjoubi, que predicaba en la mezquita Ettaouba de Bagnols-sur-Ceze, en el sur de Francia, ha negado haber cometido ning√∫n delito. Dijo a medios de comunicaci√≥n franceses que sus comentarios se hab√≠an sacado de contexto y que no pretend√≠a faltar al respeto a la bandera francesa. La bandera francesa tiene tres colores: azul, blanco y rojo.
Su abogado dijo a medios de comunicaci√≥n franceses que recurrir√° el procedimiento de expulsi√≥n.
Medios franceses publicaron extractos de la orden de expulsi√≥n, en la que se afirmaba que Mahjoubi hab√≠a "transmitido una concepci√≥n literal, retr√≥grada, intolerante y violenta del Islam, susceptible de fomentar comportamientos contrarios a los valores de la Rep√∫blica, la discriminaci√≥n de la mujer, el repliegue identitario, las tensiones con la comunidad jud√≠a y la radicalizaci√≥n yihadista".
Continuar leyendo la historia BFM inform√≥ de que Mahjoubi se encontraba en detenci√≥n administrativa en la regi√≥n de Par√≠s. Mientras que Darmanin no especific√≥ d√≥nde hab√≠a estado recluido el im√°n ni cu√°ndo, c√≥mo y d√≥nde hab√≠a sido expulsado.
Franceinfo report√≥ de que Mahjoubi se encontraba en un avi√≥n que se dirig√≠a a T√∫nez el jueves por la noche.
Darmanin se√±al√≥ que la nueva ley de inmigraci√≥n del Gobierno franc√©s, votada a principios de a√±o, hab√≠a permitido la r√°pida expulsi√≥n del im√°n.
(Reporte de Geert De Clercq; Editado en espa√±ol por Aida Pel√°ez-Fern√°ndez)

author: Fernando Bunker
title: Os 7 melhores t√™nis da ASICS para corrida em 2025
text:
A ASICS √© uma das marcas mais respeitadas no mundo da corrida, conhecida por sua dedica√ß√£o √† inova√ß√£o e ao conforto. Com uma ampla gama de modelos que atendem a diferentes necessidades e estilos de corrida, a ASICS continua a ser uma escolha favorita entre corredores amadores e profissionais. Neste artigo, destacamos os seis melhores t√™nis de corrida da ASICS, cada um projetado para oferecer desempenho superior e conforto. Vamos explorar os modelos Kayano 31, Nimbus 27, Cumulus 26, Novablast 5, Magic Speed 4 e o super t√™nis Metaspeed Sky+ para corredores profissionais. Conhe√ßa tamb√©m os melhores modelos femininos de t√™nis de corrida ASICS .
Confira abaixo a lista dos melhores t√™nis ASICS da atualidade e escolha o que mais combina com sua corrida
1. Metaspeed Sky+ Paris O ASICS Metaspeed Sky+ oi desenvolvido para corredores que buscam maximizar seu desempenho em provas longas. Este modelo foi projetado para permitir passadas mais longas e eficientes, ajudando os corredores a conservar energia e manter o ritmo em fases mais avan√ßadas da corrida. A entressola energizada com a tecnologia FF BLAST‚Ñ¢ TURBO oferece uma compress√£o melhorada e uma sensa√ß√£o responsiva na planta do p√©, proporcionando um amortecimento leve e din√¢mico. A placa de carbono inserida no cal√ßado guia a passada e impulsiona os p√©s para frente, aumentando a efici√™ncia do corredor. O solado em curva e a borracha ASICSGRIP‚Ñ¢ garantem durabilidade e ader√™ncia, mesmo em terrenos variados. Al√©m disso, o cabedal feito de Jacquard mesh melhora a respirabilidade, enquanto pelo menos 20% do material √© reciclado, refor√ßando o compromisso da ASICS com a sustentabilidade. Este t√™nis √© ideal para quem deseja come√ßar r√°pido e terminar ainda mais r√°pido, otimizando cada passo durante a corrida.
2. ASICS Superblast 2 O ASICS SUPERBLAST‚Ñ¢ 2 √© um t√™nis de alta performance projetado para proporcionar uma corrida mais responsiva e energizada do que os modelos tradicionais da linha de amortecimento da marca. Sua entressola combina FF BLAST‚Ñ¢ PLUS ECO e FF TURBO‚Ñ¢ PLUS , oferecendo amortecimento leve, absor√ß√£o eficiente de impacto e uma sensa√ß√£o de propuls√£o a cada passada. Inspirado nos modelos de elite da ASICS, como o METASPEED‚Ñ¢ , ele equilibra conforto e retorno de energia, sendo uma escolha ideal para treinos e competi√ß√µes de longa dist√¢ncia. O cabedal em engineered mesh melhora a ventila√ß√£o e se ajusta ao p√© com precis√£o, enquanto a lingueta refor√ßada evita deslizamentos, proporcionando um ajuste mais seguro. O solado, inspirado no formato de um trampolim, favorece uma passada mais responsiva, enquanto a borracha AHARPLUS‚Ñ¢ no calcanhar aumenta a durabilidade. Al√©m da performance, o modelo incorpora materiais sustent√°veis no processo de tingimento da palmilha, reduzindo o impacto ambiental. Com detalhes refletivos para maior visibilidade, o SUPERBLAST‚Ñ¢ 2 √© uma excelente op√ß√£o para corredores que buscam leveza, efici√™ncia e conforto em cada quil√¥metro .
3. ASICS Nimbus 27 O ASICS GEL-NIMBUS‚Ñ¢ 27 redefine o conceito de conforto para corredores, proporcionando uma experi√™ncia de amortecimento que faz voc√™ se sentir como se estivesse correndo nas nuvens. Com um cabedal em jacquard mesh, o modelo oferece respirabilidade e um ajuste confort√°vel, enquanto a lingueta e o forro em knit adicionam maciez e suporte aos p√©s. A tecnologia PureGEL‚Ñ¢ garante aterrissagens suaves, e o amortecimento FF BLAST‚Ñ¢ PLUS ECO, composto por materiais reciclados, proporciona leveza e responsividade a cada passada. Al√©m disso, o solado com borracha HYBRID ASICSGRIP‚Ñ¢ melhora a tra√ß√£o e durabilidade, tornando o Nimbus 27 ideal para longas dist√¢ncias com conforto superior.
4. ASICS GEL-Kayano 3 1 O ASICS GEL-KAYANO 31 √© uma evolu√ß√£o significativa dentro de uma das linhas mais renomadas da marca, elevando o conceito de estabilidade e conforto premium para novos patamares. Esta vers√£o foi projetada para oferecer suporte adapt√°vel, especialmente durante treinos de longa dist√¢ncia, gra√ßas ao inovador sistema 4D GUIDANCE SYSTEM‚Ñ¢ que proporciona uma passada mais equilibrada e segura. A entressola conta com a tecnologia de amortecimento FF BLAST‚Ñ¢ PLUS ECO, que oferece uma combina√ß√£o √∫nica de leveza, responsividade e sustentabilidade, enquanto a tecnologia PureGEL‚Ñ¢ garante aterrissagens suaves e uma prote√ß√£o adicional contra impactos.
5. ASICS Gel-Cumulus 27 O lan√ßamento ASICS GEL-CUMULUS‚Ñ¢ 27 √© uma excelente escolha para corredores que buscam conforto, versatilidade e desempenho em diferentes dist√¢ncias e treinos. A combina√ß√£o das tecnologias FF BLAST‚Ñ¢ PLUS e PureGEL‚Ñ¢ na entressola proporciona aterrissagens suaves e uma pisada mais energizada, promovendo uma experi√™ncia de corrida leve e eficiente. O solado com tecnologia FLUIDRIDE‚Ñ¢ contribui para transi√ß√µes mais suaves entre as passadas, enquanto o cabedal em mesh respir√°vel e materiais reciclados garante conforto t√©rmico e sustentabilidade. Com palmilha OrthoLite‚Ñ¢ X-30, puxador traseiro para facilitar o calce e detalhes refletivos para maior visibilidade, o Cumulus 27 entrega um pacote completo para quem busca performance sem abrir m√£o do conforto.
6. Novablast 5 O ASICS Novablast 5 foi lan√ßado em Dezembro de 2024 e √© conhecido por sua incr√≠vel capacidade de retorno de energia. Este modelo √© ideal para corredores que procuram um t√™nis leve e √°gil, capaz de proporcionar uma corrida din√¢mica e energizante.
7. Magic Speed 4 O ASICS MAGIC SPEED 4 √© a escolha ideal para corredores que buscam alcan√ßar novas metas com mais estabilidade e impulso. Este modelo foi atualizado para proporcionar uma experi√™ncia de corrida mais suave e responsiva, gra√ßas ao amortecimento FF TURBO‚Ñ¢ que oferece maior leveza e flexibilidade, resultando em uma sensa√ß√£o energizada a cada passo. A placa de carbono embutida na entressola ajuda a estabilizar a passada e a criar uma transi√ß√£o mais propulsora durante a fase inicial do ciclo de pisada. O cabedal em Engineered Mesh melhora a respirabilidade, mantendo os p√©s frescos e bem ajustados, enquanto o solado de borracha ASICSGRIP‚Ñ¢ garante excelente tra√ß√£o em diferentes superf√≠cies. Al√©m disso, com um foco em sustentabilidade, pelo menos 50% do material do cabedal √© feito de materiais reciclados, refor√ßando o compromisso da ASICS com a redu√ß√£o de desperd√≠cios e emiss√µes de carbono. O MAGIC SPEED 4 √©, sem d√∫vida, um t√™nis que combina tecnologia avan√ßada e desempenho superior para quem quer melhorar sua performance em treinos e competi√ß√µes.
Conclus√£o Em resumo, a ASICS se destaca com sua linha de t√™nis de corrida que combina inova√ß√£o, conforto e sustentabilidade. Do Kayano 31, ideal para estabilidade e longas dist√¢ncias, ao Metaspeed Sky+, projetado para desempenho profissional, cada modelo atende a necessidades espec√≠ficas dos corredores. O Nimbus 27 oferece amortecimento superior, enquanto o Cumulus 26 √© vers√°til para diversos treinos. O Novablast 4 proporciona um retorno de energia incr√≠vel, e o Magic Speed 3 √© perfeito para velocidade e competi√ß√µes. Com essas op√ß√µes, a ASICS garante uma experi√™ncia de corrida excepcional para todos os n√≠veis e objetivos.

author: NewsBreak Original
title: Islanders bounce back from horrific loss with convincing win over Capitals
text: The Islanders practiced angry on Thursday and said all the right things after a shocking 7-0 defeat at the hands of the Penguins on Wednesday. But Lane Lambert hit the nail on the head Friday morning when asked about the response of the group. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll see tonight,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúTonight‚Äôs the response.‚Äù It ended up being just the response the Islanders needed, in the form of a dominant 5-1 win over the Capitals that will allow them to wash the memory of Wednesday from their minds. After a shocking structural effort in which they were repeatedly victimized around their own net on Wednesday, the Islanders turned in a much sharper game in their own end. They settled things down, moved the puck through the neutral zone as planned and got in on the forecheck ‚Äî a basic return to fundamentals. It began to pay off when the Isles scored twice over a stretch of 1:10 early in the second period, first when Jean-Gabriel Pageau went bar-down on a breakaway one-timer and second when Noah Dobson‚Äôs one-timer off Mathew Barzal‚Äôs drop pass beat Darcy Kuemper from above the right circle. Perfect, the Islanders were not; that is rare in general and rarer for this team. But it was about as close as they have gotten all year. Julian Gauthier‚Äôs finish from the slot off Jean-Gabriel Pageau‚Äôs rebound at the 10:10 mark of the third, however, spared the Islanders from the sort of late-game drama to which they have become accustomed. Eighteen seconds later, when Gauthier slid the puck past Kuemper off another Pageau feed, it spelled an end to the competitive portion of the evening. Pageau, however, still had another goal in his bag to cap a four-point evening by making it 5-0 with 5:34 to go in the game. So was this progress compared to Wednesday? Yes, it sure was. The top six was much more dynamic offensively. Gauthier, after being made a healthy scratch for the first time since Nov. 24 on Wednesday, loudly reaffirmed he should be in the lineup ahead of Oliver Wahlstrom. Pageau had arguably his best night of the season and heard his name sung by the fans. Sorokin, after getting pulled Wednesday, looked like his usual impeccable self and stopped 32 shots, only losing a shutout on Nicolas Aube-Kubel‚Äôs goal with 17.9 seconds left. The Islanders limited their defensive zone time and limited Washington‚Äôs chances, save for the early part of the third when they fell into old habits while protecting the lead. After allowing four or more goals in three of their last five games, that was an absolute necessity on Friday. The Islanders are still hurting on the back end with three defensemen on injured reserve. But the six that they have were all pulling on the rope Friday. That must continue. One bad loss was not going to shake the confidence of a group that has never diverted from its own self-belief. But a failure to respond to that loss would have opened up some big questions about character, accountability and whether that self-belief had much foundation in reality. The tests will not stop coming anytime soon for the Islanders, who will try and get revenge on the Penguins on Sunday in Pittsburgh before heading out west for three games all against teams currently in playoff positions. Now, though, they can get on the plane with some renewed self-confidence.

author: nordbayern.de, N√ºrnberg, Germany
title: Tarifeinigung f√ºr D√∂nerfabrik Birtat
text:
Arbeitskampf
Tarifeinigung f√ºr D√∂nerfabrik Birtat
08.08.2025, 10:35 UhrDie Besch√§ftigten beim D√∂nerspie√ü-Hersteller Birtat zerkleinern Fleisch, marinieren und stecken es dann auf die Spie√üe - ein Knochenjob. F√ºr sie gilt k√ºnftig nach Gewerkschaftsangaben der erste Tarifvertrag in der D√∂nerfleischindustrie. In ihm wurde der Einstiegslohn auf 2.600 Euro festgelegt, wie die Gewerkschaft Nahrung-Genuss-Gastst√§tten (NGG) und das Unternehmen Meat World SE (Birtat) in Murr bei Ludwigsburg gemeinsam mitteilten. F√ºr Betriebsratschef Muzayfe Doganer ist mit dem Haustarifvertrag ‚Äûein Traum‚Äú wahr geworden. ‚ÄûIch wollte weinen.‚Äú Er sei stolz auf die rund 120 Mitarbeiter. Es sei ein Ergebnis, das f√ºr beide Seiten gut sei.
Ferner sei eine Anhebung der Entgelte in zwei Stufen im Gesamtumfang von bis zu 17 Prozent in der Spitze bei einer Laufzeit bis Ende 2026 vereinbart worden, wie beide Seiten mitteilten.
Die Gewerkschaft NGG hatte eine Erh√∂hung der Entgelte um monatlich 375 Euro und einen Tarifvertrag gefordert. Die Besch√§ftigten legten ihre Arbeit an elf unterschiedlichen Tagen zeitweise nieder.
NGG-Verhandlungsf√ºhrerin Magdalena Kr√ºger sagte, dieser Tarifabschluss sei ein historisches Ergebnis in der D√∂nerfleischbranche und ein Erfolg der Besch√§ftigten.
Unternehmenssprecher Cihan Karaman sagte laut der gemeinsamen Mitteilung: ‚ÄûWir sind √ºberzeugt, dass dieser Vertrag nicht nur Planungssicherheit schafft, sondern auch das Vertrauen und die Zusammenarbeit zwischen Unternehmen und Besch√§ftigten st√§rkt.‚Äú Der Vertrag ist ein Haustarifvertrag, weil er zwischen der Gewerkschaft und dem Unternehmen abgeschlossen worden ist.
Verband: 400 D√∂nerhersteller in Deutschland
Die Tarifauseinandersetzung wurde in den vergangenen Wochen mit harten Bandagen gef√ºhrt. Beide Seiten mussten Zugest√§ndnisse machen. In der zweiten Urabstimmung votierten rund 90 Prozent der befragten NGG-Mitglieder f√ºr die Annahme des Tarifvertrags.
Die Tarifparteien verpflichten sich zudem, nun √ºber einen Tarifvertrag zur Eingruppierung sowie einen Manteltarifvertrag zu verhandeln. Die Gewerkschaft hofft, dass sie k√ºnftig gleichfalls bei anderen Unternehmen der Branche tarifvertragliche Regelungen durchsetzen kann. DGB-Landeschef Kai Burmeister sagte, der Tarifabschluss bei Birtat sei ein toller und hart erk√§mpfter Erfolg f√ºr die Besch√§ftigten und die NGG.
Birtat geh√∂rt zur Meat World SE, nach NGG-Angaben der gr√∂√üte Hersteller von D√∂nerspie√üen in Baden-W√ºrttemberg - und einer der f√ºhrenden Anbieter in Deutschland. In der Fabrik stecken die Mitarbeiterinnen und Mitarbeiter Fleisch vom Kalb, H√§hnchen oder Rind auf Spie√üe - und geben dem Ganzen die traditionelle Form. Die Spie√üe werden dann schockgefrostet und ausgeliefert.
Birtat versorgt nach eigenen Angaben Tausende Imbisse und erreicht mehr als 13 Millionen Konsumentinnen und Konsumenten monatlich. ‚ÄûUnsere Produkte kann man fast in jeder gro√üen Stadt in Europa verkosten‚Äú, sagte ein Firmensprecher k√ºrzlich. Man sei Marktf√ºhrer. Meat World machte demnach zuletzt einen Jahresumsatz von ungef√§hr 200 Millionen Euro. Nach Angaben des Verbands der D√∂nerproduzenten gibt es etwa 400 D√∂nerhersteller hierzulande.

author: REDACCI√ìN BOL√çVAR
title: La Feria ‚ÄúSembradores de Paz‚Äù dej√≥ un balance positivo en Bol√≠var | EL UNIVERSAL - Cartagena
text: Con el objetivo de apoyar a las v√≠ctimas del conflicto armado, el Servicio Nacional de Aprendizaje en Bol√≠var se sum√≥ a la Feria de Emprendimiento ‚ÄúSembradores de Paz‚Äù, gracias a alianza con el Multicentro La Plazuela en Cartagena y la participaci√≥n de unidades productivas lideradas por personas v√≠ctimas pertenecientes a los programas SENA Emprende Rural (SER), Fondo Emprender y varios vinculados a Sistema de Responsabilidad Penal para Adolescentes. [Lea: Renta ciudadana y Renta Joven: as√≠ puedes consultar si tu giro lleg√≥](https://www.eluniversal.com.co/cartagena/renta-ciudadana-y-renta-joven-asi-puedes-consultar-si-tu-giro-llego-AB10442075) En total, al cierre de la jornada, el valor de las ventas alcanzadas por los emprendimientos entre el p√∫blico asistente al Multicentro La Plazuela fue de $32.155.000, con lo cual se impulsa el trabajo digno y se mueve la econom√≠a campesina y popular de la Regi√≥n, apoyada por el SENA. Arte y Dise√±o Zen√∫, Artesan√≠as Palma de Iraca, Artmy Colombia, Dulces Wadnipar, L√°cteos Para√≠so, Kamai, MaryCrea, Surizadai, Bomboimbo, Casa Artesana, Fruylac, Chococampo y Pupy Frut, son los nombres de los emprendimientos participantes que pertenecen a diversos sectores tales como: artesan√≠as, gastronom√≠a, turismo y textiles, entre otros. [Lea: SENA reconstruye vivienda destruida por invierno y la entrega a su due√±a](https://www.eluniversal.com.co/regional/sena-reconstruye-vivienda-destruida-por-invierno-y-la-entrega-a-su-duena-NG10432708) In√©s Yepes, coordinadora de la Agencia P√∫blica de Empleo en Bol√≠var, afirm√≥: ‚ÄúEstamos muy contentos de apoyar a nuestra poblaci√≥n v√≠ctima del conflicto armado en Bol√≠var. Queremos resaltar que durante la feria asistieron 600 personas para respaldar a los emprendedores, quienes lograron vender productos por m√°s de 30 millones de pesos‚Äù. Desde los municipios El Carmen de Bol√≠var, Magangu√©, Mahates, Marialabaja, San Jacinto, San Juan Nepomuceno, Turbaco; Cartagena y los corregimientos San Basilio de Palenque, San Cayetano y San Crist√≥bal, se movilizaron estos emprendimientos participantes. ‚ÄúEstamos muy agradecidos por la oportunidad que nos brinda el SENA para dar a conocer nuestro negocio. Estos espacios nos permiten crear relaciones comerciales y llegar a nuevos mercados con nuestros emprendimientos‚Äù, asegur√≥ Mar√≠a Isabel Medina D√≠az, creadora de la marca MaryCrea, la cual se dedica al dise√±o y confecci√≥n de prendas de vestir inspiradas en mujeres reales, adapt√°ndose a diferentes estilos y tallas. En 2023, en Bol√≠var se orientaron a 18.630 v√≠ctimas del conflicto armado. Adem√°s, se asesoraron a 20 emprendedores v√≠ctimas, quienes resultaron beneficiarios de la convocatoria del Fondo Emprender. Tambi√©n 64.834 personas con formaci√≥n titulada y complementaria.

author: #ThisIsTucson staff
title: 80 fun events happening in Tucson this January 2024
text:
Welcome to our first event list of the year, Tucson! üéâ
As 2024 kicks off, a slew of annual events make their return: Tucson Jazz Festival, Zopp√© Family Circus, Dillinger Days and the massive gem show. Artsy shops are hosting manifestation and vision board workshops and there are still a few more chances to see holiday lights before the twinkling decor gets packed up until next winter.
Of course, things can change quickly these days. Check for the latest info before heading out!
LightsUp! A Festival of Illumination
You have one last weekend to take a stroll through the Tucson Botanical Gardens' holiday light show. Walk through luminaria displays and 1 million twinkling lights.
When: 6-9:30 p.m. Tuesday-Sunday through Jan. 7
People are also reading‚Ä¶
Where: Tucson Botanical Gardens,
2150 N. Alvernon Way
Cost: $20-$50 for adults and $18-$45 for kids, depending on the day.
Tucson Holiday Ice
Tucson's pop-up ice skating rink is here for one last weekend! Skates, which begin at size 8 for kids and go up to size 15 for men, are included in the admission price. Socks are required and gloves are recommended.
When: Now through Jan. 7
Where: Tucson Convention Center,
260 S. Church Ave.
Cost: A 90-minute session is $22 for adults, $15 for kids under 12 years old. The first session of each day is discounted to $12 for adults, $8 for kids. Book your tickets online.
ZooLights Holiday Magic
Reid Park Zoo's annual ZooLights is here for one more weekend. Find colorful light displays, falling snow and festive music.
When: Now through Jan. 7
Where: Reid Park Zoo,
3400 E. Zoo Court
Cost: $13 for general admission; $8 for kids ages 2-14. Bring a donation of two cans of food, a pet toy, an unwrapped children's toy or non-functioning holiday lights to recycle and receive $1 off admission.
First Thursday at Tucson Museum of Art
Visit the Tucson Museum of Art every first Thursday of the month for pay-what-you-wish admission, gallery activities, meditation, live music and a cash bar. This month's event will also feature Moroccan sandwiches from La Merguez and Syrian Sweets from Marwa Alfandi.
When: 5-8 p.m. Thursday, Jan. 4
Where: Tucson Museum of Art,
140 N. Main Ave.
Cost: Pay what you wish
Safe Shift Store 3-Day Sale
The Safe Shift estate store, which helps raise funds for firefighters and first responders through the Greater Tucson Fire Foundation, opens its doors for three days each month. Past items for sale have included furniture, home decor, kitchen items, books and more.
When: 8 a.m. to 3 p.m. Thursday-Saturday, Jan. 4-6
Where: Safe Shift,
2801 E. Grant Road
Cost: Free to attend, bring money for shopping
Odyssey Live Storytelling
Attend this live storytelling event to hear stories surrounding the theme of "inner monologue."
When: 7-9 p.m. Thursday, Jan. 4
Where: The Screening Room,
127 E. Congress St.
Cost: $15
Winter Family Science Workshops: Field Trip to the Moon
Learn all about the moon at this workshop where families will be able to make a moon crater and model the phases of the moon.
When: 10-11:30 a.m. Thursday, Jan. 4
Where: Flandrau Science Center & Planetarium,
1601 E. University Blvd.
Cost: $25 for kids, free for every adult per child. $15 for each additional adult.
Discovery Nights at Children's Museum Tucson
Visit Children's Museum Tucson for a free night of science and art, including story times and pop-up science experiments.
When: 5-7 p.m. Thursdays
Cost: Free to attend
Art Corner with BICAS
Get free access to recycled bike art parts, tools and other materials and get creative! Once you're finished, you can donate your creation to BICAS or give a suggested donation to the nonprofit, if you're able to. Check in at the front counter before heading to the art area.
When: 3-6 p.m. Thursdays
Where: BICAS,
2001 N. Seventh Ave.
Cost: Free to attend, donation suggested
Zopp√© Family Circus
Zopp√© Family Circus, featuring Nino the Clown and a cast of seven generations of Zopp√©s, makes its way back to Tucson this winter. Expect acrobatic acts, a trapeze artist, a ringmaster and more. The circus has been a January tradition in Tucson since 2011.
When: Jan. 5-21
Where: Mercado District,
100 S. Avenida del Convento
Cost: $25 for general admission, $45 for ringside
Broadway Rave
This traveling rave is basically a big musical theater dance party "celebrating the best of Broadway."
When: 9 p.m. Friday, Jan. 5
Where: 191 Toole,
191 E. Toole Ave.
Cost: $15-$20. This event is for ages 18 and up.
New Year Magickal Manifestation
The Ninth House's founder Melisa Doran will lead a two-hour workshop all about manifestation, setting intentions and spell casting.
When: 6-8 p.m. Friday, Jan. 5
Where: The Ninth House,
2563 E. Fort Lowell Road
Cost: $40
"Adventure Time" Trivia at the Short Rest Tavern
Fridays are for trivia at the Short Rest Tavern, a hidden bar tucked inside Tucson Mall's Tucson Games and Gadgets. This Friday, test your knowledge on all things "Adventure Time."
When: 7 p.m. Friday, Jan. 5
Where: Short Rest Tavern in Tucson Mall,
4500 N. Oracle Road
Cost: Free to attend, bring money for drinks. Tables are first come, first served. Park between Dillard's and Sears.
Magic & Mystery Dinner Theater
At this event, you'll get to enjoy dinner from Dante's Fire, all while watching a magical theatrical performance.
When: 6:30 p.m. Fridays, Jan. 5-12
Where: Dante's Fire,
2526 E. Grant Road
Cost: $49 without dinner, $79 with dinner
Tucson Trades
Indoor market Tucson Trades made its debut last summer and they're doin' it again this winter. More than 100 vendors are set to be at the market, selling items like baked goods, jewelry, soaps and candles.
When: 2-8 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 6
Where: Tucson Convention Center,
https://www.google.com/maps/place/Tucson+Convention+Center/@32.2178071,-110.9740303,15z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0x6d21704396556f42?sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjbg_3fk9v_AhVoJkQIHXQMCZYQ_BJ6BAhGEAg
Cost: Free to attend, bring money for shopping
Free First Saturday at Valley of the Moon
Local fantasy park Valley of the Moon opens its doors for free this Saturday. The park will be hosting a donation drive for Make Way For Books ‚Äî bring new or gently used books to donate.
When: 3-5 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 6
Where: Valley of the Moon,
2544 E. Allen Road
Cost: Free to attend
First Saturday ArtWalk
The Warehouse Arts Management Organization is hosting its First Saturday ArtWalk this weekend, where you can walk through several local galleries and artist studios.
When: 5-8 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 6
Where: See the map
here
Cost: Free to attend
Creative Kind Workshops
Maker shop Creative Kind has two artsy events on the calendar this January. This weekend, create your own 2024 vision board. On Jan. 25, the shop is hosting a "Court of Thorns and Roses"-themed art night.
When: 11 a.m. to 2 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 6 for the vision board; anytime 6-9 p.m. Thursday, Jan. 25 for the art night.
Where: Creative Kind,
2905 E. Skyline Dr.
Cost: $55 for the vision board workshop; $15 for the art night.
Story Time Character Hour
The University of Arizona BookStores are hosting monthly Story Time Character Hours for kids ages 2-5 years old. There will be reading and crafts, plus the chance to take photos with storybook characters. This month, Daniel the Tiger will be there.
When: 10:30 a.m. and 2 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 6
Where: The University of Arizona BookStores,
1209 E. University Blvd.
Cost: Free to attend
Beer + Bikes
This bike ride goes along The Loop to 1912 Brewing Co. for a beer or two, followed by a ride back to Button Brew House for food truck bites.
When: 11 a.m. Saturday, Jan. 6
Where: Button Brew House,
6800 N. Camino Martin
Cost: Free to attend, bring money for brews and food
St. Philip's Plaza Market
Visit St. Philip's Plaza to shop from local makers from silversmiths to candle makers.
When: 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. Saturdays and Sundays
Where: St. Philip's Plaza,
4280 N. Campbell Ave.
Cost: Free to attend, bring money for shopping and food
Walking tours with the Presidio Museum
Explore Tucson with walking tours hosted by the Presidio Museum. Among this month's tours: see murals around downtown, check out mansions along Main Avenue and learn about historical architecture.
When: Various dates, check out the calendar
https://tucsonpresidio.com/calendars/.
Where: Locations vary based on tour.
Cost: $25. Pre-registration may be required for these events.
Medella Vina Antique and Vintage Fair
Once a month, Medella Vina Ranch hosts an antique fair where you can shop vintage items from more than 100 vendors, plus take a break at an onsite food truck.
When: 8 a.m. to 2 p.m. on the first Sunday of the month.
Where: Medella Vina Ranch,
4450 S. Houghton Road
Cost: Free to attend, bring money for shopping and food
Goat yoga
Enjoy an hour of yoga and goats with these classes at Udall Park!
When: 9-10 a.m. or 2-3 p.m. select Saturdays and Sundays in January
Where: Northeast of the Udall Pool building at Udall Park,
7290 E. Tanque Verde Road
Cost: $25
Solar Observing with Tucson Amateur Astronomy Association
Learn about the sky with Tucson Amateur Astronomy Association! The group is hosting a solar observing event this weekend.
When: 1-3 p.m. Sunday, Jan. 7
Where: Saguaro National Park East,
3693 S. Old Spanish Trail
Cost: Park entrance fee is $25 per car
Libra & Thorn Workshops
Metaphysical art shop Libra & Thorn is hosting a slew of workshops to kick off the new year. Among them: tarot basics and manifestation candles.
When: Several dates
Where: Libra & Thorn,
101 S. Pantano Road
Cost: Prices vary based on workshop
TKMA Presents: Sunday Brunch Series
The Tucson Kitchen Musicians Association, aka the folks who put on the Tucson Folk Festival each spring, are hosting a concert this Sunday with music by Jacob Acosta and Peter Dalton Ronstadt.
When: 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. Sunday, Jan. 7
Where: Monterey Court,
505 W. Miracle Mile
Cost: Free to attend
Cat events at El Jefe Cat Cafe
Spend time with the cats at El Jefe Cat Cafe! January events include bingo, sound bath meditation and yoga.
When: Various dates in January.
Where: El Jefe Cat Cafe,
3025 N. Campbell Ave.
Cost: Prices vary based on event.
Live storytelling with F*ST Female Storytellers
F*ST, Female* StoryTellers, is back with a night of live storytelling. This time, the night will be centered around the theme "sobering."
When: 7 p.m. Tuesday, Jan. 9
Where: The Rock,
136 N. Park Ave.
Cost: $10
Trivia at Crooked Tooth Brewing Co.
Test your knowledge in all things "Seinfeld," "The Office" and "Ted Lasso" at these trivia nights. Teams can have as many as five people!
When: 7 p.m. Tuesdays: Jan. 9 for "Seinfeld," Jan. 23 for "The Office," Jan. 30 for "Ted Lasso." Teams are signed up on a first come, first served basis. It's suggested to get there by 6 p.m. to secure your spot.
Where: Crooked Tooth Brewing Co.,
228 E. Sixth St.
Cost: Free to attend, recommended to buy a drink or two!
Gather A Vintage Market
Find all kinds of vintage and antique home and garden items at this four-day market.
When: 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Thursday-Saturday, Jan. 11-13; 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. Sunday, Jan. 14
Where: Gather A Vintage Market,
300 S. Park Ave.
Cost: Free to attend, bring money for shopping
Tucson Jazz Festival
January in Tucson means jazz. The theme for this year's HSL Properties Tucson Jazz Festival is "Join the Party." Expect musicians like Arturo Sandoval, Trombone Shorty and Calexico.
When: Jan. 12-20
Where: Several locations
Cost: Varies. A free fiesta takes place Jan. 15.
Tucson International Jewish Film Festival
From Jan. 11-31, dozens of films will be screened as part of the Tucson International Jewish Film Festival. Some films will be screened in person throughout the Tucson area. Others will be available to screen virtually.
When: Jan. 11-31
Where: Several locations
Cost: $60 for six films, $120 for all films (or $135 after Jan. 8)
Tasting History: Herbs
Learn about the origins behind herbs like lemongrass and cilantro and how they became part of Tucson's agricultural and culinary traditions. Demonstrations and tastings are part of the fun.
When: 9-11 a.m. Friday-Saturday, Jan. 12-13
Where: Mission Garden,
946 W. Mission Lane
Cost: Free to attend, donations accepted
Rockin' Minerals
Shop minerals, fossils and jewelry alongside hands-on geology activities for kids at the Arizona-Sonora Desert Museum.
When: 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Saturday-Sunday, Jan. 13-14
Where: Arizona-Sonora Desert Museum,
2021 N. Kinney Road
Cost: Museum admission is $29.95 for adults ages 13 and up ($24.95 for Arizona and Sonora residents). Kids ages 3-12 get in for $19.95.
Japanese New Year Festival 2024
Celebrate the Year of the Dragon at Yume Japanese Gardens of Tucson. Watch live performances, enjoy Japanese food and see the annual mochitsuki ritual, which is the pounding of rice to make mochi.
When: 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 13
Where: Yume Japanese Gardens of Tucson,
2130 N. Alvernon Way
Cost: $18 for adults, $6 for kids. Advanced registration is required.
Sahuarita Art on the Lake Festival
Experience art in Sahuarita! You'll have the chance to shop local artwork and enjoy interactive art activities, such as a community chalk mural competition. There will also be live music and food trucks.
When: 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 13
Where: Sahuarita Lake Park,
15466 S. Rancho Sahuarita Blvd.
Cost: Free to attend, bring money for shopping and food
Bowie Tribute at Surly Wench
Surly Wench Pub is hosting a Bowie tribute this January, featuring performers, giveaways and a vendor selling dark jewelry.
When: 9 p.m. to 2 a.m. Saturday, Jan. 13
Where: Surly Wench Pub,
424 N. Fourth Ave.
Cost: $5
Art After Dark at Children's Museum Tucson
Each month, Children's Museum Tucson hosts Art After Dark with local arts groups and free admission!
When: 5:30-7:30 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 13
Cost: Free to attend
Tucson Repair Cafe
Need something fixed? Bring it to the Tucson Repair Cafe to be fixed for free! All items are welcome.
When: 4-8 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 13
Where: Xerocraft Makerspace,
101 W. Sixth St.
Cost: Free to attend
2nd Saturdays
Check out food trucks, live music and local makers during this monthly outdoor street festival.
When: 5-10 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 13
Where: Downtown Tucson along
East Congress Street
Cost: Free to attend, bring money for shopping and food
Second Saturday at Steam Pump Ranch
The second Saturday of every month is special at Steam Pump Ranch. Find historic tours of the grounds, demonstrations led by Archaeology Southwest, crafts for kids, vendors selling their artwork and a farmers market.
When: 9 a.m. to 1 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 13
Where: Steam Pump Ranch,
10901 N. Oracle Road
Cost: Free to attend, bring money for shopping
Stargazing with Tucson Amateur Astronomy Association
Go stargazing with Tucson Amateur Astronomy Association at Agua Caliente Park! The group will have several telescopes available.
When: 6:30-8:30 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 13
Where: Agua Caliente Park,
12325 E. Roger Road
Cost: Free to attend, registration required
Silent Adventures
Silent disco meets flash mob with Silent Adventures! Put on your headphones and dance your way through downtown Tucson.
When: 3:30 p.m. Saturdays, Jan. 13-20
Where: Joel D. Valdez Main Library,
101 N. Stone Ave.
Cost: $25 for adults, $15 for kids
Chez Peachy Bento Cake Workshop
Chez Peachy is known for her colorful lunchbox-size cakes. Come Jan. 13, she'll teach you how to decorate your own cake to take home.
When: 4-6 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 13
Where: The Monica,
40 E. Congress St.
Cost: $50
Living History Day
Head to Living History Day at the Presidio Museum to learn about the types of jobs people had in the 18th and 19th centuries. There will be demonstrations like blacksmithing and soldier drills, plus music and tortilla tastings.
When: 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 13
Where: Presidio San Agust√≠n del Tucson Museum,
196 N. Court Ave.
Cost: $9 for adults, $6 for kids ages 6-13
Bachata Social Dance Night
Put on your dancing shoes for a night of music and mingling! Enjoy a bachata class followed by social dancing.
When: 8 p.m. to midnight Saturday, Jan. 13
Where: Tucson Creative Dance Center,
3131 N. Cherry Ave.
Cost: $15, cash or Venmo
Second SundAZe at TMA
Visit the Tucson Museum of Art every second Sunday for pay-what-you-wish admission. Enjoy art-making, gallery activities, family yoga and a performance by AZ Peruvian.
When: 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Sunday, Jan. 14
Where: Tucson Museum of Art,
140 N. Main Ave.
Cost: Pay what you wish
Mercado Flea
Check out more than 45 vendors selling antique and vintage items at the Mercado Flea.
When: 8 a.m. to 2 p.m. on the second Sunday of each month through May.
Where: Mercado District,
https://www.google.com/maps/place/Mercado+San+Agustin/@32.2201355,-110.9856285,15z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0x40b972c33497401f?sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjtje746aT6AhXFKkQIHdF8CdUQ_BJ6BAhdEAU
Cost: Free to attend, bring money for shopping
Tucson Desert Song Festival
This music festival kicks off Jan. 14 and goes through Feb. 15, with a spring leg March 2 through April 9. The lineup includes two world-class tenors in Michael Fabiano and Lawrence Brownlee.
When: Jan. 14-Feb. 15; March 2-April 9
Where: Several locations.
Cost: Varies.
"Mean Girls" Trivia Night
Test your knowledge in all things "Mean Girls" during this trivia night at Snakes & Lattes.
When: 7-9 p.m. Wednesday, Jan. 17
Where: Snakes & Lattes,
988 E. University Blvd.
Cost: $10 for general admission, $32 for a 4-person table
Sonoran Cinema at Tohono Chul
Visit Tohono Chul's Sonoran Cinema for an indoor screening of "The Wizard of Oz." Get cotton candy and popcorn from the concession stands!
When: 7 p.m. Friday, Jan. 19
Where: Tohono Chul,
7366 N. Paseo del Norte
Cost: $4
Whitney Listening Party
Roux Events is hosting a listening party at Revel Wine Bar, featuring Whitney Houston's greatest hits.
When: 8-10:30 p.m. Friday, Jan. 19
Where: Revel Wine Bar,
416 E. Ninth St.
Cost: $15 for reserved seating
Be Our Guest: The Disney DJ Night
From "High School Musical" and "Hannah Montana" to "Frozen" and "The Lion King," this Disney night will spin all your fave Disney hits at The Rialto.
When: 9 p.m. Friday, Jan. 19
Where: The Rialto Theatre,
318 E. Congress St.
Cost: $18-$20. This event is for ages 18 and up.
Mamma Coal's Dolly Hoot
Local musician Mamma Coal is hosting this tribute to Dolly Parton, sharing her favorite Dolly songs alongside other Tucson country artists.
When: 7:30 p.m. Friday, Jan. 19
Where: 191 Toole,
191 E. Toole Ave.
Cost: $12-$20. This event is for ages 21 and up.
Queer Speed Dating
Find your next date or make a new friend at this queer speed dating event!

Where: Bawker Bawker Cider House,
400 N. Fourth Ave.
Cost: Free to participate with the purchase of one drink. This event is for ages 21 and up.
SAVOR Food and Wine Festival
SAACA hosts this annual festival in celebration of Southern Arizona's culinary arts. Walk the Tucson Botanical Gardens for tastings from more than 50 of our region's chefs, wineries, breweries and restaurants.

Where: Tucson Botanical Gardens,
https://www.google.com/maps/place/Tucson+Botanical+Gardens/@32.248523,-110.908785,15z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0x1ebe7fc3dd8c6453?sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjz0ZjP_t-BAxW6NEQIHbqHCdkQ_BJ6BAgxEAA&ved=2ahUKEwjz0ZjP_t-BAxW6NEQIHbqHCdkQ_BJ6BAg6EAg
Cost: $115
Zoom Zoom at Children's Museum Tucson
Children's Museum Tucson's transportation-themed event is back!
When: 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 20. The museum itself will be open 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. with pay-what-you-wish admission all day.
Cost: Free to attend
Dirty T Market
Kicking off in January, local spicy candy shop Dirty T Tamarindo will be hosting a monthly market featuring vendors, low riders, food trucks and games.
When: 4-10 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 20
Where: Dirty T Tamarindo,
1211 W. St Marys Road
Cost: Free to attend, bring money for food and shopping
Family Saturdays with Watershed Management Group
Head to Watershed Management Group for Family Saturdays where you'll learn about bugs, birds and bats in the Sonoran Desert.
When: 9 a.m. Saturday, Jan. 20
Where: Watershed Management Group,
1137 N. Dodge Blvd.
Cost: Free to attend
Tanque Verde Market
This market brings local creatives to the east side! Find about two dozen vendors offering pottery, home decor, skin-care products, plants, clothing and more.
When: 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 20
Where: Forty Niner Country Club,
12000 E. Tanque Verde Road
Cost: Free to attend, bring money for shopping
Make N Take at Pima Air and Space
Kids ages 6 and up will receive a quick-build model aircraft kit that they'll be able to put together, all while learning about the aircraft itself. Kids will also get to visit the aircraft they're set to build.

Where: Pima Air and Space Museum's administrative building north of the parking lot,
6000 E. Valencia Road
Cost: $20 per child. An adult is required to be present with the child during class. Admission to the museum is not included and admission is not needed to participate in the class.
Flow for the Soul with Flam Chen
Flam Chen and In-Rave are hosting a flow night with DJs, vendors and flow art performances. Proceeds go to the All Souls Procession.
When: 6-10 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 20
Where: MSA Annex,
267 S. Avenida del Convento
Cost: $10
Dillinger Days
A fire that broke out at Hotel Congress in 1934 led to the capture of the infamous Dillinger gang. Each year, the hotel puts on Dillinger Days with reenactments of the capture, vintage cars and live music.
When: 10 a.m. Sunday, Jan. 21. There will also be a
Dillinger Speakeasy at 7 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 20.
Where: Hotel Congress,
311 E. Congress St.
Cost: Dillinger Days are free to attend; the speakeasy is $19.06.
Fruit Cocktail Lounge
Head downtown for an LGBTQ+ cocktail party and social at The Century Room at Hotel Congress! Enjoy cocktails, small plates and entertainment.
When: 4 p.m. Sunday, Jan. 21
Where: The Century Room,
https://www.google.com/maps/place/Hotel+Congress/@32.222248,-110.966648,15z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0xdffb6a03465761fd?sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwixr9iz84L4AhXagY4IHV_XDlwQ_BJ6BAhpEAU
Cost: $10. This event is for ages 21 and up.
First Avenue Flea
There's a new antique market in town ‚Äî and it's indoors!
When: 7 a.m. to 2 p.m. every third Sunday of the month.
Where:
3239 N. First Ave.
Cost: Free to attend, bring money for shopping
Minor Mutiny Mural Unveiling
Tucson's Museum of Contemporary Art is home to Minor Mutiny, a leadership program for teens. The group painted a mural at the Tucson Jewish Museum and Holocaust Center and will unveil it on Jan. 21.
When: 2-3 p.m. Sunday, Jan. 21
Where: Tucson Jewish Museum and Holocaust Center,
564 S. Stone Ave.
Cost: Free to attend
Tucson Fringe Festival
This 12th annual performing arts festival is back for another year, featuring more than two dozen shows. The festival is said to be unjuried and uncensored to ensure inclusivity.
When: Jan. 24-28
Where: Three downtown venues, plus virtual performances
Cost: $25 for two shows, $55 for five shows
Cinema Tucs√≥n: "T√≥tem"
Watch a screening of "T√≥tem," which follows seven-year-old Sol as she prepares for her father's birthday party. Called poignant and emotionally expansive, the film will be screened in Spanish with English subtitles. Cinema Tucs√≥n is presented by Cinema Tropical and the University of Arizona Center for Latin American Studies.
When: 7 p.m. Wednesday, Jan. 24
Where: Fox Tucson Theatre,
17 W. Congress St.
Cost: $10
Night at the Museum: Minis & Sip
The Mini Time Machine Museum of Miniatures is pairing miniatures with wine! Alongside wine and small snacks, you'll get to create your own mini bar cart.
When: 5:30-8 p.m. Thursday, Jan. 25
Where: The Mini Time Machine Museum of Miniatures,
4455 E. Camp Lowell Dr.
Cost: $40. This event is for ages 21 and up.
Fire Show at Sky Bar
The Cirque Roots Fire Troupe puts on a 20-minute fire show every fourth Friday, right outside of Sky Bar.
When: 8:15 p.m. Friday, Jan. 26
Where: Sky Bar,
536 N. Fourth Ave.
Cost: Free to attend
Tucson, Gem, Mineral & Fossil Showcase
The giant Tucson Gem, Mineral & Fossil Showcase is back for yet another winter season, bringing people from allover the world to shop the dozens of shows spread out across the city. Find jewelry, rocks, fossils and more.

La Encantada Fine Art Festival
SAACA is hosting a fine art festival at La Encantada, featuring artists selling items that range from mixed media to paintings to sculptures. You'll also find live music and art demonstrations.
When: 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 27; 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. Sunday, Jan. 28
Where: La Encantada Shopping Center,
https://www.google.com/maps/place/La+Encantada/@32.3248317,-110.9296576,15z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0x66d7a30348efe79f?sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwi3wv6npfP8AhU4EEQIHckuAUQQ_BJ6BAhLEAg
Cost: Free to attend, bring money for shopping
Retro Game Show Night
Retro Game Show Night, an evening of off-the-cuff comedy that pays homage to old TV game shows with a funky twist, returns with "The Wheel of Misfortune."
When: 7 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 27
Where: Club Congress,
https://www.google.com/maps/place/Hotel+Congress/@32.222248,-110.966648,15z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0xdffb6a03465761fd?sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwily8v7wtP3AhV_JEQIHWEaAJUQ_BJ6BAhfEAU
Cost: $19.06. This event is for ages 21 and up.
A Day at the Alfie
To kick off the gem show, the Alfie Norville Gem & Mineral Museum is hosting a day of free admission and guest speakers.
When: 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 27
Where: Alfie Norville Gem & Mineral Museum,
115 N. Church Ave.
Cost: Free to attend, reserve seats online for presentations
Visit the
event page for more information.
Plant Vibes
Come Jan. 27, The Boxyard will host an event that features a plant swap with Plantney, comedy with Lady Haha, music, cocktails and drag.
When: Noon to 5 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 27
Where: The Boxyard,
238 N. Fourth Ave.
Cost: Free to attend, bring money for food and shopping
Visit the
https://www.instagram.com/p/C1C_dIAv-ma/ for more information.
Laser Shows at Flandrau
Flandrau's laser shows for Taylor Swift and Prince are already sold out this month, but there are two more music-themed laser shows on the roster: Laser Foo Fighters and Laser Beastie Boys.
When: Saturday, Jan. 27. 7-8 p.m. for Foo Fighters; 8:30-9:30 p.m. for Beastie Boys.
Where: Flandrau Science Center & Planetarium,
1601 E. University Blvd.
Cost: $18.95 for laser shows and admission to science exhibits
Metal Fest
The Rialto is hosting Metal Fest as part of its Local Love Presents series. The concert features a local lineup of musicians.
When: 7 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 27
Where: Rialto Theatre,
318 E. Congress St.
Cost: $5-$8
Family Funday: Find the Thief
The Presidio and Fort Lowell museums are hosting a Family Funday where attendees will use clues to find the thief of a necklace.
When: 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 27
Where: Fort Lowell Museum,
2900 N. Craycroft Road
Cost: $3
Vision Valley Fest
This rave, hosted by the folks behind the Visionary House Market, is taking place at Valley of the Moon with DJs across three stages, local vendors, food trucks and a silent disco.
When: 2-10 p.m. Sunday, Jan. 28
Where: Valley of the Moon,
2544 E. Allen Road
Cost: TBA

author: Alastair Baker News Editor
title: Positive response to Brewery Hill trail plans | APG State News | bozemandailychronicle.com
text:
The overall takeaway to proposed plans to provide a walking trail down Brewery Hill was one of enthusiasm and positivity if last week‚Äôs meeting is anything to go by.
Approximately 100 residents turned out to hear Brandon Duffey, PE, GreatWest Engineering talk about the recently conducted feasibility study.
The study was carried out at the request of the Red Lodge CCE, Alpine Basin HOA, and the Red Lodge Urban Renewal Agency. If supported City could pursue MDOT TA grant application that would be due April 9.
If awarded the design process would being in 2026 with construction 2027.
The estimated cost would be just over $1 million with a local match requirement of 13.42 percent amounting to $140,357 that would include 20 percent contingency and 4 percent inflation to 2027 costs.
The favored plan is to add to the existing north side trail at Lazy M taking it down passed the entrance to Alpine Basin where a crosswalk to the south side of the Highway will be installed allowing residents to walk down the south side of Brewery Hill.
The cross walk at Alpine Basin is considered a safer option because of better visuals for traffic and people.
Duffey said that the study took into account obvious obstacles such as the narrow corridor, utilities, the pond on the south side, and the wetlands on the north side wetland, along with driveway approaches, and ADA crossings.
At the meeting Duffey took into consideration a request for extending the lighting along Highway 78 to make it safer for people walking.
Concerns were raised regarding the placement of the proposed crosswalk just at the top of Brewery Hill especially as the hill ices up in winter but were addressed by suggestions to reduce the speed limit to 25 mph. Duffey said he would talk to MDOT about this at the next meeting.
Mayor Dave Westwood added that he was concerned about coming out of Alpine.
‚ÄúIt is less scary than pulling a left from Lazy M, and if there is a cross walk there, it does push MDOT to lowering the speed limit further up that hill.‚Äù
A suggestion was made to extend the path from the Rodeo Grounds, as there was already a cross walk there and keeping the path on one side.
Duffey thought it was a valid point but questioned if people were going to walk down the north side to the present cross walk only to cross and then start back the way they came but on the south side.
Duffey acknowledged there was a safety concern with Word Ave. coming on to Brewery Hill and proposed walkways and it needs evaluation.
He added it is a ‚Äúchallenging intersection.‚Äù
